div.p:
I have the honor to enclose copy of a letter which I have received from Mr D. Horowitz,
The enclosed letter was written by D. Horowitz, Forest Conservator, of West Kensington, to J. Cashel Hoey, of the Agent General's Department, London, on 30 November 1882. He wrote saying he had received a request from the Danish Government asking for a report on the 'feasability of rearing Eucalypts in the Danish possessions of the West Indies and which species' he would recommend, and authorising him to buy suitable seeds. He had been unable to buy seeds and so was writing to Hoey to see if he could obtain the following seeds: 1/2 lb of E. globulus and 1/4 each of E. platyphylla and E. obliqua. He was still collecting information for his report but as the species named 'will grow almost anywhere' wished to at least start with them. The seeds were to be forwarded to the Governor of Santa Cruz, Christiansted, West Indies.
T. Wilson, Under Secretary, forwarded the correspondence to M on 25 January 1883 'for report as to the best means of obtaining a supply of these seeds.' formerly of the Victorian Forest service, and lately employed by the French Government in planting the Eucalypt in Algeria.
He is desirous of obtaining a small parcel of three kinds of Eucalyptus seed for the Danish Government who wish to try to what extent Eucalypts can be reared in their West Indian Colonies.
I have no doubt you will be happy to comply with the wishes of His Danish Majesty's Government, and I would draw to your attention that Mr Horowitz's suggestion as to forwarding it here.
